title: Project Integration Basics
description: Understand how to coordinate all project management activities into a cohesive whole.
objectives: Understand integration as the PM's primary responsibility
Recognize how all project elements connect and influence each other
Apply holistic thinking to project decisions
Manage trade-offs between competing project demands

screens.headline: Why Is Alex Always in Meetings?

dialogue.text: Alex, you're in meetings all day! When do you actually DO the work? I'm cooking, contractors are building—what exactly is your job?

screens.learningHook: The PM's job IS integration—connecting all the pieces. Without integration, you have activities but not a project. The PM is the glue that holds everything together.

screens.title: Integration Decision Making
screens.instructions: A change request comes in. As PM, you must consider how it impacts ALL project elements and make an integrated decision.

scenario.title: The Scope Change Request
scenario.request: Ava (investor) wants to add an outdoor patio seating area (wasn't in original scope).

questions.question: What project areas must Alex consider before approving this change? Select ALL that apply.

options.text: Schedule impact (will it delay opening?)
Budget impact (can we afford $75K more?)
Risk impact (weather delays, permits)
Stakeholder impact (does Carlos approve?)
Resource impact (do we have workers available?)
Quality impact (same standards for outdoor?)
Alex's personal preference

questions.question: Carlos approves the budget but says 'the opening date CANNOT move.' What is Alex's integration challenge?

options.text: No challenge—just add the scope and work faster
Must find ways to add scope without extending schedule (more workers, parallel work, or accept risk)
Tell Ava 'no' since the schedule is fixed
Ignore the schedule constraint since the sponsor approved budget

questions.question: Match each integration action to the correct purpose:

items.action: Update project schedule with patio tasks
Add weather delay to risk register
Get Carlos and Ava alignment on trade-offs

questions.question: What is the PM's PRIMARY role in integration?

options.text: Do all the work personally
Connect all elements, identify impacts, and ensure alignment across the project
Delegate everything to specialists
Report status to stakeholders

content.definition: Integration is the PM activity of combining, connecting, and coordinating all project elements into a unified whole.
content.analogy: Like an orchestra conductor who doesn't play instruments but makes all musicians play together harmoniously.
content.insight: Without integration, you have separate activities. With integration, you have a PROJECT.

blocks.title: Why Integration is the PM's Core Job

content.reality: Specialists manage specific areas (Maya manages kitchen, contractors manage construction). The PM manages the CONNECTIONS.

examples.focus: How construction affects kitchen, how budget affects schedule, how all pieces fit together

content.keyQuestion: If everyone manages their piece, who manages the whole? THE PM.

activities.name: Develop Project Charter
activities.integration: Connects business need to project objectives

activities.name: Develop Project Management Plan
activities.integration: Combines all subsidiary plans (scope, schedule, cost, etc.) into cohesive whole

activities.name: Direct and Manage Project Work
activities.integration: Coordinates execution of all work packages

activities.name: Manage Project Knowledge
activities.integration: Connects lessons learned to future decisions

activities.name: Perform Integrated Change Control
activities.integration: Evaluates changes across ALL project areas

activities.name: Close Project
activities.integration: Ensures all elements are properly concluded

content.definition: Reviewing all change requests to assess their impact across the ENTIRE project.
process: Assess impact on scope, schedule, cost, quality, risk, resources
If approved, update ALL affected plans

impacts.stakeholders: Ava happy, Carlos concerned about timeline

content.insight: NEVER evaluate a change in isolation. Always consider cross-impacts.

content.mindset: See the forest AND the trees. Every decision ripples across the project.
questions: If I change this, what else is affected?
Who needs to know about this change?
Does this align with project objectives?

antiPattern.name: Siloed thinking
antiPattern.problem: Solving one problem while creating three others
antiPattern.example: Approving overtime to meet schedule—without considering budget impact, team burnout risk, or quality decline

content.insight: The PM who thinks holistically anticipates problems. The PM who thinks in silos reacts to them.

screens.title: Integration in Action
screens.context: A contractor reports that plumbing will be 1 week late due to material shortage. As integrating PM, what does Alex do?

questions.question: What areas must Alex evaluate due to the plumbing delay?

options.text: Schedule: Does this delay other work?
Cost: Are there delay penalties or expedite fees?
Risk: Could material shortage affect other areas?
Stakeholders: Does Carlos/Ava need to know?
Quality: Can we use substitute materials?
Alex's vacation schedule

questions.question: Alex finds that the 1-week plumbing delay cascades into a 2-week project delay. What's the best integrated response?

options.text: Blame the contractor and demand they fix it
Present options to Carlos: accept delay, pay to expedite, or adjust scope
Hide the delay and hope to recover later
Immediately extend the project by 2 weeks without consulting anyone

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: Integration is the PM's core job—connecting all project elements into a cohesive whole. Think holistically; every change ripples across the project.
takeaways: Integration = combining, connecting, coordinating all project elements
The PM is like an orchestra conductor—doesn't play instruments, makes them play together
Specialists manage pieces; PM manages the WHOLE
Integrated Change Control: Never evaluate changes in isolation
Holistic thinking: Every decision has cross-impacts
Ask: 'If I change this, what else is affected?'

artifacts.title: Change Impact Assessment Template
artifacts.description: Checklist for evaluating changes across all areas

artifacts.title: Integration Web
artifacts.description: Visual showing how all project elements connect

characterClosing.text: Now I understand, Alex. You're not 'in meetings all day'—you're making sure my kitchen connects to the contractor's work, the budget, the timeline, and Carlos's expectations. That IS the job.

nextLesson.title: Identifying Stakeholders
nextLesson.teaser: Congratulations! You've completed the Foundation path. Now dive into the People Domain—starting with deep stakeholder identification and engagement.

screens.congratulations: You've mastered the fundamentals! You now understand projects vs operations, your role as PM, stakeholders, life cycles, organizational structures, constraints, success factors, and integration. Ready for the People Domain!
